text: We have a version of the Local HubL Server which utilizes Docker nearly in a place to be used. Should help avoid issues like yours <@UHUNYTXU4>. <@UKERKEEGZ> no need to look into it :smile_cat:
<@U6W3H6YN8> That’s great to hear! I actually was a researching a implementation for docker as well, thanks!
How will this affect ease of config?
Almost like a lighter virtualbox instance. The Java dependancies etc... would be bundled and preconfigured with the docker image itself. If I'm understanding correctly.

Not to distract from local server talk... but does anyone use a Chrome extension or app that will output the fonts actually being used on a particular web page? almost like uncss, but just a list of fonts?

not sure it’s what you’re meaning but if you just want to know the fonts actually being rendered for specific elements there’s a special rendered font listing under the computed tab in chrome.

If you’re wondering for more of a design reason like “list all fonts on the site” in general, I don’t use one but recently saw one that was pretty cool

<@U26BLKGE4> see if this fits your needs <https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/css-peeper/mbnbehikldjhnfehhnaidhjhoofhpehk?hl=en>

I think it might list out the fonts, as well as all colors used on the page

Would think it would be pretty simple, like uncss. Looks at the elements that render on a page, looks through and parses the styles associated with those elements, then returns the font families and weights actually being used, just in a list. Ideal use case is like if a page is loading all possible font weights and variants for like three or four fonts, but only actually uses 3 styles. I'd just want a list of Raleway: 400, 600, Open Sans 700.
when you activate it shows the right pane, showing all the fonts on page with weights.
When you highlight over it shows font, font size, weight, line spacing etc. Super useful for QA as well
look at that. they even have a ff extension
